description.narrative: Vegetable consumption in the Philippines is very low, particularly in the poorer provinces and regions of Samar, Mindanao, Leyte and Bohol. Low vegetable production rates are largely to blame, in turn mainly due to issues of poor soil fertility. This project will focus on commonly grown vegetables such as eggplant, ampalaya, bell pepper, tomatoes and leafy vegetables. Its overall aim is to develop soil and nutrient management practices for smallholder farmers in this region to increase cost-effective production of vegetables. Research will investigate soil fertility constraints and identify locally appropriate strategies to address these. One of the main outputs will be integrated management practices for increasing productivity of vegetables while sustaining the natural resources. Through reducing input costs and increasing yields for smallholder farmers, the availability and cost of vegetables for consumers will be improved.
